ProjectDesc: The second and final volume of a two volume biography of James Boswell, entitled James Boswell; The Later Years, written in collaboration with Frederick A. Pottle. Intended to be the standard biography of Boswell, this work is based mainly on materials in the Yale Boswell collection. The first volume was published in 1966. The second volume will include an extensive critical examination of Boswell's two major biographical studies.
ProjectTitle: James Boswell: The Later Years (A Biographical and Critical Study)

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Saul', 'Lastname': 'Touster', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1978-02-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: Study will be a close examination of the "texts" of Holmes's life— his judicial opinions, his speeches and his letters—using the tools of new criticism and psychological theory. The moral passage of Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr., from young Abolitionist, volunteering and wading through a "sea of blood," to judge on the Massachusetts Supreme Court, skeptical and aloof, offers striking parallels to what happened to the spirit of the country at large after the Civil War. Focus will be on how this transformation of character, in Holmes and in the country, from 1860 to 1900, was effected and its "style" and psychology will be identified.
ProjectTitle: The Moral Passage of Justice Holmes: Judgment and Character in the Gilded Age

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Herbert', 'Lastname': 'Gutman', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1978-12-01T00:00:00'}

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center

ProjectDesc: To address the nature of the changing work experience and the relationship between it and larger social and cultural processes. The purpose of the seminar is to put the contemporary "crisis" over work into a meaningful historical perspective.
ProjectTitle: Profession Seminar Entitled "Americans at Work: Changing Social and Cultural Practices"

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Herbert', 'Lastname': 'Gutman', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1977-12-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: A seminar for labor leaders which will address the changing work experience and the relationship between it and larger social and cultural processes. Four historic work patterns shall be examined: pre-industrial, industrializing, industrial, and contemporary. Attention shall focus on workers outside and inside the labor movement and on rural as well as urban workers.
ProjectTitle: Americans at Work: Changing Social and Cultural Practices

ProjectDesc: To write a book with the intent of investigation and unraveling some of the connections between "modernist" (or modernistic) culture and modernized (or modernizing) society.  The focus will be on selected people, situations, and ideas in Europe and America, over the last 2 centuries.
ProjectTitle: All That is Solid Melts in the Air: A Study of Modernism and Modernization

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Abraham', 'Lastname': 'Ascher', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, City College', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1974-09-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To examine in depth the Russian Revolution of 1905, beginning with a study of the domestic repercussions to the Russo-Japanese War in 1904 and ending with an account of Stolypin's coup d'etat of 1907 which marked the final triumph of the autocracy over the opposition.  The Revolution of 1905 is significant because it differed from any other revolution in Europe during the 18th and 19th centuries, and foreshadowed convulsions that have taken place in various underveloped countries in recent years.
ProjectTitle: The Russian Revolution of 1905

ProjectDesc: To study and explain how and why the Reaissance relied upon the study of mathematics as a serious and integral part of the training of artists.
ProjectTitle: Science and Art in the Renaissance (with Special Attention to Mathematics and Theories of Perspective)

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Pamela', 'Lastname': 'Sheingorn', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1978-09-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To examine drama dealing with the Resurrection of Christ in relation to the iconography of this theme in medieval painting and sculpture. It is based on a methodology which has found artistic evidence most pertinent to a full understanding of this drama. Study will show how the scene was constructed and its impact on an audience and will examine its place in the cycle plays.
ProjectTitle: The Resurrection in Art and Drama

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Marcel', 'Lastname': 'Gutwirth', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1978-01-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: Readings in theory of laughter and the comic, ranging from Aristotle to contemporary research in psychology, ethology, and stylistics. Inquiry as to the relationship between theory and practice. Comedies of Moliere and Shakespeare will invite consideration of French and Anglo-Saxon practice, and of the theory which diverges from it. Reading will also include Beckett, perhaps by way of Rabelais and Joyce, Tati and Chaplin.
ProjectTitle: Theory of the Comic and the Art of Comedy

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Mary', 'Lastname': 'Caws', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1978-01-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: A study of poetics, specifically of relations between theme and form, drawing on examples from twentieth-century European and American literature with particular emphasis on French and Spanish poetry.
ProjectTitle: Poem and Metapoetics: Theory, Theme and Text

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Arnold', 'Lastname': 'Rogow', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1978-01-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To investigate the relevance of psychological theories and concepts to biographical study of political leaders. The central assumption the seminar is that political roles and careers are significantly affected by unconscious as well as conscious variables. The seminar will explore a variety of behavioral and psychoanalytic theories and their applications to political biography. Psychological and non-psychological biographies of the same individual will be compared and contrasted.
ProjectTitle: Psychoanalysis and Psychobiography

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Morris', 'Lastname': 'Dickstein', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1978-01-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: A seminar exploring the relationship between changes in contemporary society and changes in literary style and content. American writing, from 1950 to the present, will be viewed in terms of the changes in sensibility, culture and social life during that period. The course will use the cultural resources of New York City to explore parallel developments in other creative arts.
ProjectTitle: Contemporary Literature in its Cultural Context

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Allan', 'Lastname': 'Atlas', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1973-06-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To develop a greater understanding of the interrelationships that exist between the arts on one hand and the other forces that shape and influence society on the other.  The study will focus of musical life in Perugia during the late 15th and 16th centuries.
ProjectTitle: Study of the Chansonnier Perugia (Biblioteca Comunale MS 431) and of Musical Life in 15th and 16th Century Perugia

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Mary', 'Lastname': 'Caws', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1974-06-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To continue work on a book on Rene Char, a great living French poet, called The Presence and Poetry of Rene Char.  Two projects are being undertaken: thorough consultation of the author's manuscripts and discussion with the poet about certain of his poems which he had previous been unwilling to discuss with anyone.
ProjectTitle: The Poetry of Rene Char: Another Reading

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Morris', 'Lastname': 'Dickstein', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1975-07-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To continue work on a book on the changes in American culture and sensibilities during the 1960's. Stipend will be used to write chapter on popular culture of period, including film, music, and other performing arts; and a concluding chapter on social conflict in the sixties.
ProjectTitle: The Sixties and After: American Culture and Sensibility in Transition

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'William', 'Lastname': 'Helmreich', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1977-07-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To study the reason for the implications of the survival of yeshivas in modern America.  Yeshivas are religious institutions where individuals study the Talmud and other aspects of Jewish law and tradition. Their purpose is to produce an educated laity as well as to train rabbis and theological educators. Amazingly, these institutions have been in existence for over 2,000 years. The project has two goals: (1) to account for the survival of the yeshiva as an integral part of the Jewish community, (2) to present an accurate and detailed account of what life is like in these institutions. Participant observation, and interviewing, and analysis of existing literature will be conducted.
ProjectTitle: A Study of Rabbinical Seminaries in America and How They Have managed to Adapt and Survive in Modern Society

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Norman', 'Lastname': 'Kelvin', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, City College', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1974-07-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To reevaluate Morris's character, writings, influence upon taste in the decorative art and architecture; and his role as a 19th century English political thinker.  Morris's relationship to other important Victorians will be redefined.  The letters will be arranged chronologically.  Annotations will identify persons, events and technical procedures.
ProjectTitle: A Comprehensive Edition of the Letters of William Morris (1834-96)

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'W. Speed', 'Lastname': 'Hill', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Lehman College', 'City': 'Bronx', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1974-07-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: This project, undeway since 1968, is a multi-volume edition, critically edited with full commentary, of the complete works of Richard Hooker, one of the major prose writers of the early English Renaissance.  The edition is to be published by Harvard University Press.  NEH funds will be used to see the first volumes into press and to monitor progress on subsequent volumes of commentary.
ProjectTitle: New Critical Edition of the Works of Richard Hooker

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Norman', 'Lastname': 'Kelvin', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, City College', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '1976-01-01T00:00:00'}
ProjectDesc: To edit the letters of William Morris (1834 to 1896). The edition will contain an introduction reevaluating Morris' character, writings, influence upon taste in the decorative arts and architecture; and his role as a 19th century English political thinker. Morris' relationship to other prominent Victorians will be defined. The letters will be arranged chronologically.
ProjectTitle: A Comprehensive Edition of the Letters of William Morris (1834-96)

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center

ProjectDesc: RILM Abstracts of Music Literature, the widely used guide to scholarly writings about music, is seeking to expand its scope to include one of the most valuable repositories of music research, one that has been all but inaccessible to researchers: articles published in Festschriften before 1967. Festschriften have always been within RILM’s scope of coverage, which began in 1967. But neither RILM nor any other bibliography comprehensively indexes the contents of these volumes from before then, although they include many significant, groundbreaking studies by scholars who have since been recognized as seminal figures in Western musicology, ethnomusicology, music librarianship, performance practice, and other related fields.
ProjectTitle: Abstracts of Music Literature: pre-1967 Festschriften
ToSupport: The abstracting and indexing of pre-1967 Festschriften in music for inclusion in the series, "Abstracts of Music Literature."

Participant: {'Firstname': 'John', 'Lastname': 'Graziano', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '2009-07-17T08:45:19.720'}
ProjectDesc: Music in Gotham: The New York Scene, 1862-1875, from Selected Printed Sources, will offer researchers comprehensive information on musical life in New York City, the country's leading musical center during the Civil War and its aftermath. Little such information is available at present. During the 2010-2012 proposed grant, data collected and synthesized by the Music in Gotham staff for the years 1862-1869 will be entered into an open access web-based resource to document the performance and reception of music in the city. The design of the Data Input Module is complete and is fully functional. This proposal requests funding for (1) the inputting of data into the Input Module, (2) the design and development of the Basic Search Interface, and (3) the launching of the website at the Graduate Center/CUNY for access by the scholarly community and other interested researchers.
ProjectTitle: Music in Gotham: The New York Scene, 1862-1875, from Selected Printed Sources
ToSupport: The development of a freely accessible, online reference database documenting New York City musical culture from 1862 to 1869 using an assemblage of period advertisements, articles, and reviews.

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
ProjectDesc: A cooperative agreement for a two-and-a-half-year faculty and curriculum development project on Latino/a history for forty-two community college faculty and academic administrators in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and eastern Pennsylvania. In partnership with Queensborough Community College, the American Social History Project/Center for Media and Learning at the City University of New York Graduate Center (ASHP/CML) organizes a program of sustained study for community college faculty and administrators on the history and cultures of Latino/a communities in the United States leading to the development of curricular materials on these topics. Under the leadership of Pennee Bender and Donna Thompson Ray of ASHP/CML, the project begins with a series of six full-day seminars on Latino/a history from the colonial period to the present. Speakers for the seminar series include Virginia Sánchez Korrol (Brooklyn College, CUNY), Andrés Reséndez (University of California at Davis), Pablo Mitchell (Oberlin College), John Nieto-Phillips (Indiana University), Orlando Hernández (Hostos Community College, CUNY), Cristina Beltrán (New York University), María Josefina Saldaña-Portillo (New York University), Ramona Hernández (City College of New York, CUNY), María Montoya (New York University), and Lisandro Pérez (John Jay College, CUNY). These seminars are supplemented by an online reading discussion series and mentoring from Queensborough faculty members Megan Elias, Aránzazu Borrachero, and Amy Traver; Carlos Hernández and Patricia Mathews-Salazar from Borough of Manhattan Community College, CUNY; and Karen Miller (LaGuardia Community College, CUNY) as participants develop and implement curricular materials. A separate program helps administrators develop strategies to support the project on their campuses. The closing conference features Vicki Ruiz of University of California at Irvine, and provide opportunities for participant teams to present on their progress. Readings are drawn from the works of the project faculty, as well as from historians Samuel Truett, Raúl Ramos, María Cristina Garcia, and Jesse Hoffnung-Garskof; anthropologist Arlene Davila; and sociologist Robert Smith, among others.
ProjectTitle: Bridging Historias through Latino History and Culture: An NEH Bridging Cultures at Community Colleges Project
ToSupport: A cooperative agreement for a two-and-a-half-year faculty and curriculum development project on Latino/a history for thirty-six community college faculty and academic administrators in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and Pennsylvania.

ToSupport: A two-week summer institute for thirty college and university faculty on the visual culture of the Civil War.

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
ProjectDesc: Peer review among graduate students is stuck in the pre-digital age. This project will pilot a new approach to graduate student writing that maximizes the strengths of both social networks and online writing environments with the intended goal of using interactive technology to re-imagine the contours of graduate education. The proposed Social Paper (SP) tool will be a free, open-source, ready-to-use networked writing environment that allows scholars to disseminate and receive feedback on works-in-progress among colleagues and the public. This online platform will enliven graduate work by using robust feedback mechanisms to generate networked discussion around student writing. In addition, the platform will allow students to keep a working portfolio of all writing and an accessible, dynamic archive of feedback from both peers and professors. The startup phase will culminate with a prototype which will be tested across a number of academic communities.
ProjectTitle: The Social Paper: DH Start up Level 1
ToSupport: Development of a free, open-source online writing tool that would allow scholars, students, and teachers to share and receive feedback on works-in-progress from colleagues and broader audiences.  The tool would be incorporated into the Commons-In-A-Box software platform, and would allow users to keep an online portfolio of their work.

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
ProjectDesc: DH Box provides an innovative approach to Digital Humanities pedagogy, helping teachers introduce DH tools quickly and effectively. The project increases the speed and ease with which novice users can begin hands-on practice with DH tools and it does so by facilitating interaction with rich datasets from institutions such as the NYPL and the British Library. Because DH Box lowers technical barriers to entry, students in the humanities will be able to bypass set-up and compatibility issues and move more quickly to their own research.
ProjectTitle: DH Box: A Digital Humanities Laboratory in the Cloud
ToSupport: Development of DH Box, a web-based platform that enables researcher and student access to multiple digital humanities tools. The project is designed for institutions and individuals with minimal technical infrastructure or expertise, including community colleges and newcomers to the field.

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Program: Institutes for College and University Teachers
ProjectTitle: The Visual Culture of the American Civil War and Its Aftermath
ToSupport: A two-week institute for thirty college and university faculty members on the visual culture of the Civil War and Reconstruction.

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Stephen', 'Lastname': 'Brier', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '2015-09-18T10:00:27.697'}
ProjectDesc: Although humanities scholars widely use academic databases from publishers such as ProQuest or Gale, knowledge of how proprietary databases work is limited because their structures are dynamic and not transparent. Scholars therefore may not be aware of and cannot account for how database structures affect their interpretations of search results or text. Lack of information is an obstacle to scholarly inquiry because databases shape the questions that can be asked and the arguments that can be made through search interfaces and algorithms. Beyond Citation is a research platform that aggregates information about academic databases so that scholars can understand the significance of the material they glean. By making accessible essential information about the structures and content of databases, Beyond Citation takes an important step in updating the scholarly apparatus to encourage critical thinking about academic databases and their impact on research and scholarship.
ProjectTitle: Beyond Citation: Critical Thinking About Digital Research
ToSupport: Further development of Beyond Citation, a web-based guide to research databases in the humanities. During this phase, the project would result in thematic guides to databases in fields such as art history, history, and literature, as well as a prototype tool for use by research libraries.

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
Participant: {'Firstname': 'Jennifer', 'Lastname': 'Furlong', 'Institution': 'CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center', 'City': 'New York', 'State': 'NY', 'Country': 'USA', 'ParticipantTypeID': 'Project Director', 'ValidFr': '2016-02-11T16:00:24.247'}
ProjectTitle: The New PhD: A Renaissance of Public Education
ToSupport:
Planning
activities at the Graduate Center at the City University of New York encompass
three planning themes: 1) ways to integrate multiple career outcomes from the beginning of students' experience in graduate school; 2) collecting and
publicly disseminating data about retention rates and students' post-doctoral
career paths; 3) initiation of partnerships with non-academic
institutions.

Institution: CUNY Research Foundation, Graduate School and University Center
ProjectTitle: Learning in the Public Square: An Open Platform for Humanities Education
ToSupport:
Implementation
of an open-source learning environment, The Commons In A Box OpenLab (CBOX-OL),
that will enable sharing and collaboration across humanities courses, events,
projects and institutions.
